description:
'''Boom bap''' is a [[subgenre]] of hip-hop and music production style that was prominent in [[East Coast hip-hop|East Coast hip hop]] during the [[Golden age hip-hop|golden age of hip-hop]] from the late 1980s to the early 1990s.

The term "boom bap" is an [[onomatopoeia]] that represents the sounds used for the [[Bass drum|bass]] (kick) drum and [[snare drum]], respectively. The style is usually recognized by a main [[Loop (music)|drum loop]] that uses a hard-hitting, acoustic bass drum [[Sampling (music)|sample]] on the [[Beat (music)#Downbeat and upbeat|downbeats]], a snappy acoustic snare drum sample on the [[Beat (music)#Downbeat and upbeat|upbeats]], and an "in your face" [[Audio mixing (recorded music)|audio mix]] emphasizing the drum loop, and the kick-snare combination in particular.

Key producers include [[DJ Premier]], [[Pete Rock]], [[Buckwild (record producer)|Buckwild]] and [[Diamond D]]. Prominent [[Hip-hop|hip hop]] artists who incorporated "boom bap" in their music include [[Gang Starr]], [[KRS-One]], [[A Tribe Called Quest]], [[Wu-Tang Clan]], [[MF Doom|MF DOOM]], [[Mobb Deep]], [[Craig Mack]], [[R.A. the Rugged Man]], [[Big L]], [[Boot Camp Clik]], [[Griselda Records|Griselda]], [[Jay-Z]], [[Common (rapper)|Common]], [[Yasiin Bey]], [[Nas]], and [[The Notorious B.I.G.]]
